choices.text: Polycystic kidney
Duplicated collecting system
Chronic pyelonephritis
Hypernephroma

questions.text: The following IVP is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Duplicated collecting system

 

Option B:

 

The drooping lily sign is a urographic sign in patients with a duplicated collecting system. It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole moiety due to an obstructed (un-opacified) upper pole moiety. Wiegert-Meyer rule is followed for the duplex collecting system. Upper pole moiety is associated with obstruction and ureterocele with an ectopic bladder insertion. Vesicoureteral reflux is common in lower pole moiety.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Polycystic Kidney: On intravenous urography, "Swiss cheese nephrogram" or “Spider leg appearance”

 

Option C. Chronic Pyelonephritis: calyceal distortion

 

Option D. Hypernephroma/RCC: Soft tissue shadow of mass

 

Educational objective:

 

The drooping lily sign is a urographic sign in patients with a duplicated collecting system.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 478

choices.text: Cysts more than 2 cm
Corticomedullary differentiation is eventually lost
Enlarged kidney
Oligohydramnios

questions.text: In a patient suspected of having autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which of the following ultrasonographic findings would be least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cysts more than 2 cm

 

Option A:

 

Cysts in ARPKD are typically very small, often microscopic, and so cysts more than 2 cm in size are not characteristic of ARPKD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. As ARPKD progresses: There is disruption of the normal kidney structure, including loss of corticomedullary differentiation, which is a typical finding.

 

Option C. Kidney enlargement: Is a common feature in ARPKD due to the presence of numerous cysts throughout the renal parenchyma.

 

Option D. Oligohydramnios: May occur in the prenatal setting of ARPKD, especially when there is significant renal impairment leading to decreased urine output by the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARPKD is characterized by numerous small (<1 cm), microscopic cysts, thus "cysts more than 2 cm" is not a typical finding of ARPKD.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 486

choices.text: Neurogenic bladder
Pelvic abscess
Pelvic lipomatosis
Pelvic hematoma

questions.text: A patient presents with lower urinary tract symptoms and a history of progressive difficulty in voiding. On physical examination, there is a palpable mass in the pelvic region. Given the cystogram image provided, which of the following conditions is least likely to be the cause of the bladder's altered contour?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neurogenic Bladder

 

Option A:

 

The given image shows a pear-shaped or tear-drop shaped bladder, where the normal round or ovoid shape has been extrinsically compressed.

Neurogenic Bladder: Typically presents as a Christmas tree or pine cone appearance due to detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia and is unlikely to cause the pear-shaped or teardrop appearance seen in the provided cystogram image.

 

Neurogenic bladder causes a Christmas tree bladder as shown here:

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pelvic Abscess: Can extrinsically compress the bladder creating a pear-shaped or teardrop appearance on imaging.

 

Option C. Pelvic Lipomatosis: Excessive deposition of fatty tissue in the pelvic cavity can also compress the bladder, leading to a similar cystogram finding.

 

Option D. Pelvic Hematoma: Following trauma or surgery, a collection of blood in the pelvic area can impose pressure on the bladder, resulting in the appearance noted on the cystogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The causes of pear-shaped bladder include:

• Pelvic abscess

• Pelvic lipomatosis

• Pelvic hematoma

• Symmetrical pelvic lymphadenopathy

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 458

choices.text: Polycystic kidney
Hydronephrosis
Chronic pyelonephritis
Posterior urethral valves

questions.text: A primigravida with 18 weeks POG presents to the clinic for an anomaly scan. Oligohydramnios is noted with bladder shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Posterior urethral valves

 

Option D:

 

The keyhole sign is an ultrasonographic sign seen in boys with posterior urethral valves

 

Posterior Urethral Valves (PUV): This condition is characterized by the presence of an obstructive, congenital membrane in the posterior urethra, leading to a bladder outlet obstruction. The "keyhole sign" described in the explanation, showing a dilated proximal urethra and a thick-walled distended bladder, is characteristic of PUV, which is consistent with the ultrasound image provided. It is indeed the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants and can lead to secondary hydronephrosis, vesicoureteral reflux, and kidney damage if not treated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD): This is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys. In utero, enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts might be visualized. It does not typically present with a "keyhole sign" on ultrasound.

 

Simple renal cysts will appear anechoic with well-defined thin walls, posterior acoustic enhancement

 

 

Option B. Hydronephrosis: This condition involves the swelling of one kidney due to a buildup of urine. It occurs when urine cannot drain from the kidney to the bladder from a blockage or obstruction. Sonographically, it would show as an enlargement of the renal pelvis and calyces and not a "keyhole sign."

Hydronephrosis: dilated pelvicalyceal system

 

 

Option C. Chronic Pyelonephritis: This is a long-standing infection that leads to scarring and deformation of the kidney. Chronic pyelonephritis would show irregular, echogenic kidneys on ultrasound, which is not consistent with the provided sonographic image.

 

Chronic Pyelonephritis: Irregular and heterogeneous echotexture of renal parenchyma

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The keyhole sign is an ultrasonographic sign seen in boys with posterior urethral valves. It refers to the appearance of the proximal urethra (which is dilated) and associated thick-walled distended bladder which on ultrasound may resemble a key hole.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 466

choices.text: Grossly enlarged kidney
Focal area of hypo echogenicity
Perinephric collection (pus in the perinephric space)
Increased vascularity

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a two-day history of fever, flank pain, and painful urination. She has no significant medical history but notes recent frequent and urgent urination. On examination, she has costovertebral angle tenderness. A urinalysis shows white blood cell casts. An ultrasound of her kidneys is performed. Which of the following findings is least likely to be observed on ultrasound in this patient with acute pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increased vascularity

 

Option D:

 

Features of Pyelonephritis on Ultrasound:

 

  • Particulate matter in the collecting system
  • Abnormal echogenicity of the renal parenchyma
  • Focal/segmental hypoechoic regions
  • Diffuse or focal enlargement of the kidney, sometimes with a mass-like lesion

 

Color and power Doppler evaluation typically shows decreased perfusion in the affected parenchyma, which has been attributed to arteriolar vasoconstriction and interstitial edema in response to bacterial infection.

 

Contrary to increased vascularity, acute pyelonephritis can present with decreased perfusion in the affected parenchyma on color and power Doppler ultrasound due to arteriolar vasoconstriction and interstitial edema in response to infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gross enlargement of the kidney can be seen in acute pyelonephritis due to inflammatory edema.

 

Option B. Focal hypoechoic areas may represent regions of infection where there is inflammatory change or edema.

 

Option C. A perinephric collection could indicate an abscess formation which can be a complication of acute pyelonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sonographic features of acute pyelonephritis are decreased, rather than increased, vascularity typically observed in the affected renal parenchyma.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 418

choices.text: Oncocytoma
Perinephric cyst
Renal cell carcinoma
Angiomyolipoma

questions.text: A 28-year-old banker came in for a regular insurance check-up, in whom a hyperechoic renal lesion was incidentally detected on ultrasound after which he also underwent a CT. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Angiomyolipoma

 

In the given CT we can see an exophytic left renal mass with fat content, which is clearly suggestive of angiomyolipoma, which is a fat containing benign renal neoplasm.

 

Explanation:

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Angiomyolipoma of the kidney on CT appears as a well-defined mass within the kidney, often containing both fat (which appears as areas of low density) and denser regions due to blood vessels and muscle. Because of its composition, it can typically be diagnosed on non-contrast CT due to the presence of fat within the tumor.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 430

choices.text: Lobster claw sign
Forniceal excavation
Signet ring
Ball and socket sign

questions.text: A patient presents with nonspecific flank pain and intermittent hematuria. Intravenous pyelography is performed, which does not show the 'ball on tee' sign, but other classical features of renal papillary necrosis are present. Which of the following IVP findings is not consistent with a diagnosis of renal papillary necrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ball and socket sign

 

Option D:

 

The ball on tee sign (not ball and socket) is seen in renal papillary necrosis, not ball and socket.

 

  • This sign is actually not associated with RPN.
  • The "ball on tee" or "ring shadow" sign refers to a radiolucent ring surrounding a dense central filling defect on an IVP, seen in cases of RPN, which is likely a confusion in the provided explanation.
  • The "ball and socket" sign is classically associated with femoroacetabular impingement in orthopedic imaging, not with renal pathology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lobster claw sign:

 

  • This sign refers to the appearance of the calyces on IVP, where the central area of papillary necrosis results in a claw-like image due to the contrast outlining the necrotic area.
  • It is considered a classic sign of RPN.

 

Option B. Forniceal excavation:

 

  • Occurs when a sloughed papilla causes outpouching or excavation in the renal calyx on IVP.
  • It is another imaging manifestation indicative of RPN.

 

Option C. Signet ring sign:

 

  • This sign is produced when contrast medium outlines a sloughed or necrotic papilla in the renal pelvis or ureter, appearing as a ring of radiolucency with a central density akin to a signet ring.
  • It is an imaging hallmark for the diagnosis of RPN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ball on Tee sign in Renal Papillary Necrosis

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 416

choices.text: Acute pyelonephritis
Emphysematous pyelonephritis
Perinephric abscess
Renal abscess

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with acute onset fever and dysuria. Urine examination revealed plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Emphysematous pyelonephritis

 

Option B:

 

Given CT scan shows an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection. This is suggestive of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis (Correct Diagnosis):

 

  • It is an acute, severe infection of the renal parenchyma and surrounding tissues that results in the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma, collecting system, or perinephric tissue.
  • It is more common in diabetic patients and those with urinary obstruction.
  • The CT scan shows mottled gas collections within the renal tissue, characteristic of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute Pyelonephritis:

 

  • This is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidney and renal pelvis.
  • The CT scan might show areas of striated nephrogram or wedge-shaped areas of poor enhancement, but without the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma, which is seen in this case.

 

Option C. Perinephric Abscess:

 

  • It involves the accumulation of pus around the outside of the kidney but within the Gerota fascia.
  • CT findings typically include a fluid collection with an enhancing rim, but not the extensive gas formation within the kidney itself.

 

Option D. Renal Abscess:

 

  • This refers to a localized collection of pus within the renal parenchyma.
  • A CT scan may show a round or oval fluid collection with an enhancing rim within the renal parenchyma, but, again, not typically associated with the extensive gas pattern observed in emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scan showing an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection is suggestive of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

choices.text: Ureterocele
Horse shoe kidney
Bladder tumor
Posterior urethral valve

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician due to recurrent urinary tract infections. The mother reports that the infections have been accompanied by abdominal pain and occasional difficulty urinating. The child has no significant past medical history. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft with mild suprapubic tenderness. Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is performed, which reveals a distinctive finding in the lower urinary tract as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the IVP findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ureterocele

 

Option A:

 

The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign. It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter.

 

It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Horseshoe Kidney: A horseshoe kidney occurs when the kidneys fuse together to form a U shape. On IVP, this typically presents with the kidneys located lower in the abdomen, closer to each other than usual, and with the ureters inserting into the bladder from a more medial position compared to normal.

 

Option C. Bladder Tumor: Bladder tumors often present as filling defects within the bladder on IVP. They may appear as irregular or smooth masses depending on the size and type of the tumor

 

Option D. Posterior Urethral Valve: This is a condition most commonly seen in male infants where there is an obstructing membrane in the posterior urethra. IVP may show a dilated posterior urethra and a thick-walled bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "cobra head" sign seen on an IVP is indicative of a ureterocele, which is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter as it enters the bladder, often causing urinary obstruction and potentially leading to hydronephrosis if left untreated.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 478

choices.text: MR spectroscopy
Dynamic contrast enhancement
Diffusion weighted MRI
T2W imaging

questions.text: Imaging sequences of MRI employed in PIRADS reporting scheme for prostate glands is all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MR spectroscopy

 

Option A:

 

PI-RADS (Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System)

This is a standardized reporting system used to evaluate the prostate for prostate cancer. A prostate-specific MRI is performed using a multiparametric technique that includes:

 T2-weighted imaging, dynamic contrast-enhanced study (DCE), and diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI)/ADC score.

T2W is used as the primary sequence to determine the transition zone, while DWI is used for the peripheral zone.

Each variable is given a score from 1 to 5 for each lesion, with 1 indicating a high probability of being benign and 5 indicating a high suspicion of malignancy.

MR spectroscopy: This is an advanced MRI technique that measures the chemical composition of tissues. MR spectroscopy is not typically included in the PIRADS scheme as it's more experimental and not as widely used as the other sequences for prostate imaging.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dynamic contrast enhancement (DCE): This MRI sequence evaluates the vascularity of prostate tissue by monitoring the flow of contrast agent through the gland. Rapid uptake and washout of contrast can be indicative of cancerous tissues.

 

Option C. Diffusion weighted MRI (DWI): This sequence assesses the movement of water molecules within the prostate tissue. Restricted diffusion can suggest higher cell density, which is a characteristic of malignancy.

 

Option D. T2W imaging: T2-weighted imaging is particularly useful in visualizing the anatomy of the prostate, including the zonal anatomy. It provides high-resolution images and can help distinguish between healthy and pathological tissues based on the intensity of the signal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PI-RADS (Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System) is a standardized reporting system used to evaluate the prostate for prostate cancer and includes T2-weighted imaging, dynamic contrast-enhanced study (DCE), and diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI)/ADC score.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 462

choices.text: Acute ureteric obstruction
Hydronephrosis
Acute complete arterial obstruction
Polycystic kidney disease

questions.text: A patient is undergoing an IVP study. Two minutes after administering the contrast, both kidneys are visualized. After 10 minutes of contrast administration, the left kidney is persistently visualized. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute ureteric obstruction

 

Option A:


This clinical scenario describes visualization of the left kidney with contrast after 10 minutes, even though contrast has washed off from the right side. Retention of the IV contrast agent by the kidneys for >3 minutes is called a dense persistent nephrogram. It can be caused by acute ureteric obstruction.

 

 

Delayed IVP showing Acute ureteric obstruction

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hydronephrosis: This condition is caused by the dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces, typically as a result of an obstruction below the level of the kidney. While hydronephrosis may be detected on an IVP, the lack of contrast washout from one side is more indicative of an obstruction rather than hydronephrosis itself.

 

Option C. Acute complete arterial obstruction: If there were a complete blockage of the renal artery, the affected kidney would not be visualized at all after contrast administration due to the lack of blood flow. Therefore, this is not consistent with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Polycystic kidney disease: Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is characterized by the presence of numerous cysts in the kidneys. PKD typically would not lead to the specific imaging finding of contrast retention in one kidney after 10 minutes. PKD may show enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts on imaging, but not a persistent nephrogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct diagnosis in a case where one kidney retains contrast on an IVP study while the other does not is likely acute ureteric obstruction. This is characterized by a dense nephrogram on the affected side, which persists beyond the expected time due to the obstruction preventing normal urine flow and contrast excretion.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 448

choices.text: SPC
Foley’s catheterization
MCU
CECT

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department following a skateboard accident. He complains of inability to void and there is blood at the external urethral meatus. Given the mechanism of injury and presentation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. SPC

 

Option A:

 

SPC (Suprapubic Catheterization): This is the preferred initial step in the setting of suspected urethral injury, which is indicated by the inability to pass urine and blood at the urethral meatus. SPC allows for bladder drainage without risking further damage to the urethra.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Foley's Catheterization: Normally used for urinary drainage, this is contraindicated if there is a suspicion of urethral injury due to the risk of exacerbating the damage and creating false passages.

 

Option C. MCU (Micturating Cystourethrogram): While this investigation can delineate the urethra and identify the site and extent of injury, it requires catheterization, which is contraindicated until urethral injury is ruled out.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): Although CECT can be useful in evaluating the extent of pelvic injuries, it is not the initial step in managing acute urinary retention with suspected urethral injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with suspected urethral trauma presenting with acute urinary retention and blood at the urethral meatus, suprapubic catheterization is the appropriate initial step to ensure urinary drainage and avoid further damage to the urethra.

 

APPROACH TO URETHRAL TRAUMA

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 458

choices.text: Renal angiomyolipoma
Renal oncocytoma
Renal cell carcinoma
Renal cyst

questions.text: A 55-year-old man, with a past medical history of smoking and hypertension, presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of flank pain and noticing blood in his urine. He has no fever or urinary symptoms. A comprehensive metabolic panel reveals normal renal function. To further evaluate his symptoms, a Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) scan of the abdomen is performed, as shown in the image below. Considering the patient’s history and imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Renal cell carcinoma

 

Option C:

 

The case of an elderly man with a heterogeneous large renal mass in the CECT image suggests renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

 

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. On CT imaging, it often appears as a heterogeneous mass due to varying degrees of vascularity, necrosis, or hemorrhage. It can cause distortion of the renal contour and invade the renal vein or perirenal fat.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Renal angiomyolipoma: It is typically a benign tumor composed of blood vessels, muscle, and fat. On imaging, it is often characterized by the presence of fat which can be identified as areas of negative attenuation on CT scans.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: It is another benign renal tumor. It can be difficult to distinguish from RCC on imaging alone. They may show a central scar and have a homogenous enhancement, although these are not definitive diagnostic features.

 

Option D. A renal cyst is a fluid-filled sac within the kidney: Simple cysts are common and usually benign. On CT, they appear as round, well-defined structures with water density and no enhancement after the administration of contrast material.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a heterogeneous large renal mass in an elderly patient on CECT is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma.

 

Characteristics of renal masses:

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 432

choices.text: Horseshoe kidney
Duplicated collecting system
Ectopic pelvic kidney
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of repeated urinary tract infections is evaluated with a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen. The CECT is as below. What is the most likely diagnosis inferred from the imaging findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Horse shoe kidney

 

Option A:

 

Horseshoe kidneys are the most common type of renal fusion anomaly. The CECT shows the kidney formed by fusion across the midline of two distinct functioning kidneys, one on each side of the midline. They are connected by an isthmus of either functioning renal parenchyma or fibrous tissue.

 

Kidneys can function normally, but associated with hydronephrosis, renal stones, infection, increase risk of renal cancer.

Higher incidence in Turner syndrome and Trisomies 13, 18, 21.

IVP: - Handshaking/Flower Vase Sign

IOC – CECT (CT Angiography)
Horseshoe Kidney is associated with nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain on hyperextension of spine, known as ROVSING SYNDROME.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Duplicated Collecting System: This refers to a kidney that has two ureteral structures that drain separately into the bladder. It can be associated with other urological anomalies and may predispose to urinary tract infections. On imaging, two separate collecting systems may be seen.

 

Option C. Ectopic Pelvic Kidney: It's a result of the kidney not ascending properly during fetal development. On imaging, the kidney would be found in the pelvis, not in its usual abdominal location.

 

Option D. Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma: It would not directly affect the kidneys, although it can lead to secondary effects on various organs due to mass effect or metastasis. Imaging would show a mass within the pancreas and not the characteristic imaging findings seen in horseshoe kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic imaging features of a horseshoe kidney on CECT, includes the fusion of the lower poles across the midline.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 480

choices.text: Fibromuscular dysplasia
Renal artery thrombosis
Hypertensive nephrosclerosis
Renal artery aneurysm

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient presents with a history of uncontrolled hypertension despite multiple medications. A Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) was performed, revealing the image below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fibromuscular dysplasia

 

Option A:

 

The given image shows the string of beads sign. It refers to the appearance of the renal artery in fibromuscular dysplasia which is a renovascular cause of secondary hypertension.

 

Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD): FMD is a non-atherosclerotic, non-inflammatory disease of the blood vessels that causes abnormal growth within the wall of an artery. The "string of beads" sign seen on DSA, which is characteristic for FMD, represents areas of stenosis alternating with aneurysms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Renal artery thrombosis: This is the formation of a clot in the renal artery that can cause acute kidney injury. DSA would show an abrupt cutoff of the artery where the thrombus is located, without the beading pattern seen in FMD.

 

Option C. Hypertensive nephrosclerosis: This is a chronic condition resulting from high blood pressure causing damage to the kidneys. It doesn't have a specific DSA sign and typically doesn't cause the alternating stenosis and dilatation seen in FMD.

 

Option D. Renal artery aneurysm: This refers to an abnormal enlargement or bulging of the renal artery. On DSA, it would appear as a localized saccular or fusiform dilatation of the artery rather than a "string of beads" pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibromuscular dysplasia can be identified on DSA by the "string of beads" sign, which is indicative of the disease's alternating stenosis and post-stenotic dilations. It is an important cause of secondary hypertension, especially in young women.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 424

choices.text: Renal artery aneurysms
Staghorn calculi of the kidneys
Medullary nephrocalcinosis
Putty kidney

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Staghorn calculi of the kidneys

 

Option B:

 

Staghorn calculi are large, branched stones that occupy a large portion of the collecting system within the kidney. The characteristic appearance on an X-ray is a large, staghorn-like calcification within the renal outline, as seen in the provided image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Renal artery aneurysms are typically not visible on plain X-rays unless they are calcified. They are usually identified on more advanced imaging studies such as CT angiography or MR angiography.

 

Option C. Medullary nephrocalcinosis involves the accumulation of calcium within the renal medulla. On X-ray, it would appear as diffuse, fine calcifications within the renal medulla and would not typically form a staghorn pattern.

 

Option D. Putty kidney refers to renal tuberculosis leading to autonephrectomy where the kidney becomes non-functional and may calcify. The calcifications in a putty kidney are usually irregular and do not form a staghorn pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staghorn calculi on a plain abdominal X-ray are characterized by large, branched radiopaque structures within the renal outline.

 

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 420

choices.text: Schistosomiasis
Thimble bladder
Neurogenic bladder
Bladder diverticula

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with a history of multiple sclerosis presents with urinary incontinence and frequent urinary tract infections. A cystogram is performed and reveals an irregular, spiky contour of the bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis indicated by this imaging finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Neurogenic bladder

 

Option C:

 

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination. Injury to the brain, brainstem, spinal cord or peripheral nerves from various causes including infection, trauma, malignancy or vascular insult can result in a dysfunctional bladder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Schistosomiasis may cause calcification of the bladder wall but typically does not cause the irregular, spiky contour seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Thimble bladder refers to a small capacity bladder often due to chronic inflammation, but it does not have the “Christmas tree” appearance.

 

Option D. Bladder diverticula are outpouchings of the bladder wall that can be congenital or acquired but would not give the spiky contour that is typical of a neurogenic bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the imaging features of neurogenic bladder, especially in the context of a patient with a known neurological disorder affecting bladder control.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

choices.text: Nephrocalcinosis
Putty kidney
Staghorn calculus
Psoas Calcification

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presenting with sterile pyuria. Radiograph is shown identify the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Putty kidney

 

Option B:

 

A putty kidney refers to a pattern of renal calcification associated with renal tuberculosis conventionally described on plain radiography. The calcification is characteristically very homogeneous and ground glass-like, representing calcified caseous tissue.

 

Putty kidney: The term describes the renal parenchyma's transformation into a putty-like mass due to chronic infection, typically renal tuberculosis. The calcification is homogenous and dense, giving a ground glass-like appearance on radiography, consistent with the image provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nephrocalcinosis: It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in the renal parenchyma. The calcification is usually diffuse and involves the cortex and medulla. It's often associated with hypercalcemic conditions, but the patient does not present with a ground-glass appearance on radiography.

 

Option C. Staghorn calculus: This refers to a large renal calculus that conforms to the shape of the renal pelvis and calyces, resembling the antlers of a stag. It typically causes a branched radiopaque pattern on radiography, which is not demonstrated in the image provided.

 

Option D. Psoas Calcification: This is usually secondary to chronic processes such as infection or hematoma, resulting in calcification within the psoas muscle. It would appear along the course of the psoas muscle and not within the kidney.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiographic characteristics of a putty kidney, are homogenous, ground glass-like calcification, typically associated with renal tuberculosis.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 418

choices.text: Horseshoe kidney
Medullary sponge kidney
Duplicated collecting system
Retrocaval ureter

questions.text: This characteristic IVP is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  Horseshoe Kidney

 

The given image shows the hand-shake sign which is suggestive of horseshoe kidneys. The following findings are seen in the image:

  • Both kidneys appear rotated with bilateral pelvicalyceal systems seen more end-on
  • Both lower poles are directed medially towards the spine

 

Explanation:

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Hand-shake sign in IVP is suggestive of horseshoe kidneys.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 480

choices.text: Duplicated collecting system
Polycystic kidney disease
Multi-cystic dysplastic kidney
Renal hypoplasia

questions.text: During intravenous pyelography of a patient, the left kidney could not be visualized. What condition is this suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Multi-cystic dysplastic kidney

 

Option C:

 

Non-visualization of the kidney on IP is seen in the case of multi-cystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK).

MCDK is a form of renal dysplasia characterized by:

 

  • Multiple, non-communicating cysts of varying size
  • Dysplastic parenchyma separating the cysts
  • Absence of a normal pelvicalyceal system.

 

Multi-cystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK):

 

  • A type of renal dysgenesis where the kidney consists of multiple cysts of varying sizes with the absence of a functional renal pelvis.
  • The affected kidney is typically non-functional.
  • On ultrasonography, the kidney presents with a cluster of non-communicating cysts, often described as having a "soap bubble" or "grape cluster" appearance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Duplicated collecting system:

 

  • This refers to a congenital condition where two ureteric buds form on the same side, leading to a duplication of the collecting system.
  • On imaging, two separate renal pelvices and ureters may be observed coming from one kidney.
  • It can be complete or partial and may sometimes be associated with other urinary tract anomalies.

 

Option B. Polycystic kidney disease:

 

  • A genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys.
  • These cysts can disrupt the normal structure and function of the kidneys and can lead to kidney failure.
  • On imaging, enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts are seen.

 

 

Option D. Renal hypoplasia:

 

  • A developmental defect resulting in a smaller-sized kidney that contains fewer nephrons than normal.
  • Can be due to a variety of genetic or environmental causes.
  • On imaging, a smaller kidney with decreased parenchymal thickness is observed. The overall architecture of the kidney is preserved, unlike dysplastic conditions where the internal structure is disrupted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multi-cystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK) is a condition where the kidney is replaced by multiple non-functioning cysts and no normal renal parenchyma.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 484

choices.text: Moth eaten calyces
Golf ball on tee sign
Lobster claw sign
Rim sign

questions.text: What is the earliest radiographic finding in patients with genitourinary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Moth-eaten calyces

 

Option A:

 

Moth-eaten calyces are the earliest finding in a patient with genitourinary tuberculosis, seen on IVP. It refers to the ragged, feathery calyceal outline due to irregular erosions of the calyx.

This appearance is due to necrotizing papillitis, which further progresses to form medullary cavities which eventually communicate with the collecting system.

The given image shows the signs of renal papillary necrosis: -

 

  • Central excavation with ball-on-tee appearance
  • Lobster-claw appearance
  • Signet ring appearance
  • Sloughed papilla with clubbed calyx

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Golf ball on tee sign: Renal papillary necrosis

 

Option C. Lobster claw sign: Renal papillary necrosis

 

Option D. Rim sign: Chronic hydronephrosis

 

Educational objective:

 

The earliest radiographic finding in patients with genitourinary tuberculosis is moth -eaten calyces seen on IVP.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 418

choices.text: CECT
CT Urography
DTPA scan
NCCT

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with severe pain in the lower abdomen, which is radiating to the groin. The patient also complaints of nausea and vomiting, painful urination, and blood in the urine. On examination, the patient is and be unable to find a comfortable position. What is the best investigation for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CT urography

 

Option B:

 

  • Initial investigation to diagnose urinary tract obstruction USG
  • Investigation of choice for renal and ureteric stonesNCCT KUB
  • IOC to know the functional status of kidney in obstruction- CT urography

 

CT Urography is an imaging method that combines a CT scan with a contrast agent to visualize the urinary tract. It is often used for the evaluation of hematuria and can provide detailed images of both the anatomy and the function of the kidneys and ureters. It is particularly useful in the setting of suspected urolithiasis, tumors, or structural abnormalities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide detailed images of structures within the body, enhanced by the use of a contrast material. It is used for a wide range of diagnostic applications, including evaluation of urinary tract disorders. However, it may not be the first-line investigation in the acute setting due to the contrast load on the kidneys.

 

Option C. DTPA scan (Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetate Scan) is a nuclear medicine test that evaluates renal function and perfusion. It is not typically the first choice for acute pain evaluation but can be useful in assessing renal function in chronic obstruction.

 

Option D. NCCT (Non-Contrast Computed Tomography) of the Kidney-Ureter-Bladder region is the investigation of choice for detecting urinary stones. It is preferred in the acute setting due to its speed, availability, lack of need for contrast, and high sensitivity for stone detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for detecting ureteric stones is CT Urography, as it provides detailed imaging of the urinary tract and can detect both radiopaque and radiolucent stones by highlighting filling defects within the contrast-filled urinary system. 

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allisons Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 446

choices.text: Tuberculosis
Schistosomiasis
Neurogenic bladder
Bladder carcinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. His symptoms have gradually progressed over the past 6 months. He denies hematuria or fever. On physical examination, there is no costovertebral angle tenderness, and abdominal palpation is unremarkable. His prostate exam is normal. A CT of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (CT KUB) was performed and is displayed below. Based on the imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Schistosomiasis

 

Option B:

 

The given image shows circumferential calcifications of the bladder wall with normal volume. Development of a densely calcified bladder resembling a fetal skull in the later stages is suggestive of bladder schistosomiasis.

Complication - Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of bladder

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Genitourinary tuberculosis can lead to calcification of the bladder wall, but typically, this would be irregular or nodular rather than the circumferential pattern observed here. Patients may present with irritative voiding symptoms, sterile pyuria, and hematuria.

 

Option C. Neurogenic Bladder: This term refers to bladder dysfunction caused by neurologic disorders. Imaging of the bladder might show a "Christmas tree" or "pine cone" appearance due to trabeculation and sacculation.

 

Option D. Bladder Carcinoma: This can present with hematuria, irritative voiding symptoms, or as a pelvic mass. On imaging, a bladder tumor might appear as a focal mass, potentially with irregular or nodular calcification if it is associated with chronic irritation or necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumferential calcifications of the bladder wall with normal volume is typically seen in Schistosomiasis.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 422

choices.text: Tc DTPA scan
MAG3 scan
VCUG
Tc DMSA scan

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was referred for evaluation of recurrent urinary tract infections. She suffered 4 episodes over the past 9 months and had been hospitalized twice. An ultrasound revealed bilateral hydronephrosis with dilatation of ureters. What is the investigation of choice in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. VCUG

 

Option A:

 

This clinical scenario with recurrent UTIs and hydronephrosis on US is suggestive of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). The investigation of choice in this condition is a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) or Micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

 

VUR refers to an abnormal flow of urine from the bladder to ureters and occurs in young children. This reflux predisposes to pyelonephritis by allowing the entry of bacteria into the usually sterile upper tract.

 

Technetium-99m diethylenetriamine pentaacetic acid (Tc DTPA) scan is a renal scintigraphy procedure used to evaluate renal function and blood flow, but it does not diagnose vesicoureteral reflux.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mercaptoacetyltriglycine (MAG3) scan is also a renal scintigraphy imaging used for assessing renal function and urinary drainage, yet it is not the first-line diagnostic test for VUR.

 

Option C. Voiding Cystourethrogram (VCUG) is an imaging procedure that visualizes the bladder and urethra while the bladder fills and empties. It's the investigation of choice for diagnosing vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), which is likely given the recurrent UTIs and hydronephrosis in this patient.

 

Option D. Technetium-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (Tc DMSA) scan is used for renal cortical imaging and is helpful in detecting renal scarring from pyelonephritis but is not used primarily for diagnosing VUR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice in this condition in Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) or Micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 448
